On Fri, 22 Aug 2003, Thali, Nilesh wrote:

>   Again, my point is that a large part of software being built today
>   is grunt-work, which can and should be codified in a process.

Actually, it's only grunt-work if you let it be so. My experience with
applying XP practices (particularly automatation and very agressive
refactoring) is that the grunt work tends to disappear. I've seen
situations where you end up with a few smart guys doing all the work,
and a few "grunts" sitting around that can't do anything, because they
don't have the technical sophistication to do anything but duplicate
code that's already in the system, making more work, not less, for the
senior folks.

In my current project, we don't even have any dedicated QA people; the
programmers themselves are responsible for doing all of the QA. We ended
up with a very heavily automated solution, one we never could have had
without QA staff who were programmers to the point that they could
change our software internals to make it more testable.
